thread.title: Pro-Trump crowds rally behind president in Southlake, Austin
thread.title_full: Pro-Trump crowds rally behind president in Southlake, Austin

author: Claire Ballor
title: Pro-Trump crowds rally behind president in Southlake, Austin
text:
SOUTHLAKE â About 200 people gathered in a Southlake neighborhood park Saturday to demonstrate solidarity with President Donald Trump. 
The rally in Liberty Park at Sheltonwood was one of many organized around the country by a new national group called Main Street Patriots. Pro-Trump rally beginning at Liberty Park in Southlake pic.twitter.com/oCmU9DTaxb — Claire Ballor (@claireballor) March 4, 2017 
Members of the group's Dallas branch planned the Southlake event and brought in several speakers, including local conservative talk radio host Chris Salcedo. 
Salcedo's speech wound through a mix of topics like Trump's recent allegations that his phones were wiretapped by President Barack Obama, bias in the news media, the failings of Obamacare, illegal immigration and Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Trump alleges Obama had Trump phones wiretapped during race 
Some of the biggest cheers Salcedo drew came from his response to an audience question regarding his thoughts on Trump's call for an investigation into Sen. Chuck Schumer and his involvement with Russia. 
"If we're going to criminalize talking with the Russians, let's do it," Salcedo said. "If we're going to go down that road, let's go down that road. Our current president will stand against the Russians where our former president kissed their rears." Spirit of America rally happening now in Southlake is one of many going on nationally today pic.twitter.com/HipQHmdOeH — Claire Ballor (@claireballor) March 4, 2017 
Crowds also cheered as speakers called for Trump supporters to no longer sit back as the "silent majority," but to be vocal with their beliefs and support. 
Mark Shackelford, the lead organizer of the rally, said the point of this event and the ones to follow is to "publicly support President Trump." Fran Rhodes asks talk show host Chris Salcedo a question about Obamacare at a rally in Southlake. 
(Robert W. Hart/Special Contributor) Chris Salcedo takes questions from the audience at Saturday's rally in Liberty Park. 
(Robert W. Hart/Special Contributor) Pro-Trump rally attendees applaud during a rally Saturday at Liberty Park at Sheltonwood in Southlake. 
(Robert W. Hart/Special Contributor) 
"I'm pleased with this turnout," Shackelford said. "I would have liked to see more people, but this is our first ever meeting, so hopefully the numbers will increase going forward." 
A slightly larger crowd braved the rain in downtown Austin, where about 300 people marched to the state Capitol to cheer the president. Hundred or so gathered here, toting umbrellas, signs + American flags. Patriotic music playing. #March4Trump #Austin pic.twitter.com/skGdqnNGqg — Taylor Goldenstein (@taygoldenstein) March 4, 2017 
"There have been so many protests against him, we just want to spend a day showing him there are people who support him," said Jennifer Drabbant of Austin, one of the organizers. 
The Austin American-Statesman reports that participants walked a few blocks from Wooldridge Square Park to the state Capitol for a rally that began with a prayer and then featured pro-Trump speeches. 
Similar rallies also took place in cities across the U.S., including Houston, Tulsa, Albuquerque and Washington, D.C. 
  contributed to this report. View Comments
